StudyInfo.StudyNameEntrez: NHLBI TOPMed - Centers for Common Disease Genomics (CCDG): Massachusetts General Hospital Atrial Fibrillation (MGH AF) Study

Person.Organization: UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS AT CHICAGOUNIVERSITY OF CHICAGO

Policy.ic_specific_access_term:
Use of the MGH AF Study data deposited in dbGaP is restricted to research on associations between phenotypes and genotypes. MGH AF Study data may not be used to investigate individual participant genotypes, individual pedigree structures, perceptions of racial/ethnic identity, non-maternity/paternity, and of variables that could be considered as stigmatizing an individual or group. All research must be related to the etiology and prevention of morbidity and mortality of the U.S. population consistent with the demographic distribution in the MGH AF Study. Data users will be required to obtain IRB approval for their projects from their respective institutions (please note that only full or expedited approvals will be accepted).
For the Disease-Specific Consent group, data use is limited to cardiovascular disease and atrial fibrillation.

File.filename: MGH AF Acknowledgement Statement with TOPMed 2016-10-06.pdf

GSR_Access.gsr_mode_label: Unrestricted access (institution responded that the study is not sensitive without submitting a new Institutional Certification)

ConsentGroup.title: Health/Medical/Biomedical (IRB)
ConsentGroup.name: HMB-IRB
ConsentGroup.Use-Restriction:
Use of this data is limited to health/medical/biomedical purposes, does not include the study of population origins or ancestry. Requestor must provide documentation of local IRB approval.
Use of the MGH AF Study data deposited in dbGaP is restricted to research on associations between phenotypes and genotypes. MGH AF Study data may not be used to investigate individual participant genotypes, individual pedigree structures, perceptions of racial/ethnic identity, non-maternity/paternity, and of variables that could be considered as stigmatizing an individual or group. All research must be related to the etiology and prevention of morbidity and mortality of the U.S. population consistent with the demographic distribution in the MGH AF Study. Data users will be required to obtain IRB approval for their projects from their respective institutions (please note that only full or expedited approvals will be accepted).

ConsentGroup.title: Disease-Specific (Atrial Fibrillation, IRB, RD)
ConsentGroup.name: DS-AF-IRB-RD
ConsentGroup.Use-Restriction:
Use of the data must be related to Atrial Fibrillation and related disorders. Requestor must provide documentation of local IRB approval.
Data use is limited to research related to atrial fibrillation and cardiovascular disease.

ConsentGroup.title: Exchange Area
ConsentGroup.name: EA
ConsentGroup.Use-Restriction:
Use by NHLBI WGS study investigators only There are two consent groups for this study: HMB-IRB and DS-AF-IRB-RD (Disease Specific Atrial Fibrillation-IRB-Related Diseases
For HMB-IRB: Use of this data is limited to health/medical/biomedical purposes, does not include the study of population origins or ancestry. Requestor must provide documentation of local IRB approval. Use of the MGH AF Study data deposited in dbGaP is restricted to research on associations between phenotypes and genotypes. MGH AF Study data may not be used to investigate individual participant genotypes, individual pedigree structures, perceptions of racial/ethnic identity, non-maternity/paternity, and of variables that could be considered as stigmatizing an individual or group. All research must be related to the etiology and prevention of morbidity and mortality of the U.S. population consistent with the demographic distribution in the MGH AF Study. Data users will be required to obtain IRB approval for their projects from their respective institutions (please note that only full or expedited approvals will be accepted).
For DS-AF-IRB-RD: Use of the data must be related to Atrial Fibrillation and related disorders. Requestor must provide documentation of local IRB approval. Data use is limited to research related to atrial fibrillation and cardiovascular disease.
